com.ronhorner.primes
Class PrimeUtils

java.lang.Object
  com.ronhorner.primes.PrimeUtils

public class PrimeUtils
extends java.lang.Object

Ron Horner
Number Theory and Cryptography CSCI-8566-001
Project 1

This Utility class will hold basic functions for computations on big numbers that are not available in the standard Java Library.

          Computes the Jacobi Symbol of two integers a and n
Inputs : a : the numerator for the Jacobi Symbol; n : the odd denominator for the Jacobi Symbol Output : -1, 0 or 1 Jacobi(a,n) { j := 1 while (a not 0) do { while (a even) do { a := a/2 if (n = 3 (mod 8) or n = 5 (mod 8)) then j := -j } interchange(a,n) if (a = 3 (mod 4) and n = 3 (mod 4)) then j := -j a := a mod n } if (n = 1) then return (j) else return(0) }

adapted from http://www.merriampark.com/bigsqrt.htm

getSquareRoot

public static java.math.BigDecimal getSquareRoot(java.math.BigDecimal n)

Here we use the algorithm of the ancient greek mathematitian Heron of Alexandria to find the square root of the number. It can be found in his anthology Metrica, book 1 chapter 8. The algorithm has been redone over the centuries by Newton and Ibn al-Banna.

adapted from http://www.merriampark.com/bigsqrt.htm

Parameters:
n - the BigDecimal to find the square root of
Returns:
the approximate square root.

checkPrimality

public static boolean checkPrimality(java.math.BigInteger n,
                                     boolean verboseOutput)

Check for primality using a very simple method.

We will iterate through the odd numbers X and use the big integer B to check B = 0 (mod X). If this is true then B is not prime and we exit. Otherwise we continue the search till we reach the square root of B.

Input : n : An odd integer greater than 1
Output : the answer composite or prime
sqrt := square root of n
for i = 2; i < sqrt+2; i++
if (n mod i == 0) return composite
return prime

Parameters:
n - BigInteger to check for primality
Returns:
true if the BigInteger is prime

checkTime

Utility function to output the current modulo every 30 seconds

t - the time since the last print out
Returns:

checkMillerRabin

public static boolean checkMillerRabin(java.math.BigInteger n,
                                       int t)
This primality check is significantly quick with an accuracy of 4^(-k)

This function is a direct transcription of the following psuedo code into native java as found at this address

http://www.cryptomathic.com/labs/rabinprimalitytest.html


Algorithm for the Miller-Rabin probabilistic primality test
Miller-Rabin(n,t)
Input : n : An odd integer greater than 1, t : the number of witnesses
Output : the answer composite or prime
Write n-1 = 2s * r such that r is odd
Repeat from 1 to t
Choose a random integer a which satisfies 1 < a < n-1
Compute y = ar mod n
if y <> 1 and y <> n-1 then
j := 1
while j < s and y <> n-1 then
y := y2 mod n
if y = 1 then return composite
j := j + 1
if y <> n-1 then return composite
return prime

Parameters:
n - The number in question
t - The number of witnesses.
Returns:
true if the number is most likely prime given the number of witnesses t.

findApproxNaturalLog

public static java.math.BigDecimal findApproxNaturalLog(java.math.BigInteger n)
This function simply multiplies the constant E by itself a number of times till it is larger than N.

Parameters:
n - The number to find the natural log for
Returns:
the ceiling of the natural log of n

checkMRD

public static boolean checkMRD(java.math.BigInteger n)

This function is a variation of the classic Miller-Rabin test in that it makes the function deterministic. This is done by not chosing random numbers but by working our way through all numbers from 2 to 2*ln(n)^2.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miller-Rabin_test

Parameters:
n - The number in question
Returns:
true if the number is prime for all witnesses

checkFermatPrimality

public static boolean checkFermatPrimality(java.math.BigInteger n,
                                           int w)

This is a really simple primality test.

Read more about it here
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_primality_test
Inputs : n : a value to test for primality; k : a parameter that determines the accuracy of the test
Output : composite if n is composite, otherwise probably prime
repeat k times:
pick a randomly in the range [1, n-1]
if a(n-1) mod n <> 1 then return composite
return probably prime

Parameters:
n - The number in question
w - The number of witnesses.
Returns:
true if the number is most likely prime given the number of witnesses w.

jacobiSymbol

public static int jacobiSymbol(java.math.BigInteger a,
                               java.math.BigInteger n)
Computes the Jacobi Symbol of two integers a and n
Inputs : a : the numerator for the Jacobi Symbol; n : the odd denominator for the Jacobi Symbol
Output : -1, 0 or 1
Jacobi(a,n) {
j := 1
while (a not 0) do {
while (a even) do {
a := a/2
if (n = 3 (mod 8) or n = 5 (mod 8)) then j := -j
}
interchange(a,n)
if (a = 3 (mod 4) and n = 3 (mod 4)) then j := -j
a := a mod n
}
if (n = 1) then return (j) else return(0)
}

Parameters:
a - any number greater than or equal to one and less than n
n - any odd number
Returns:
the value of the jacobi symbol (a/n)

checkSolovayStrassen

public static boolean checkSolovayStrassen(java.math.BigInteger n,
                                           int w)
This is a very good and very fast primality check. It is remarkably accurate when using around 100 witneses. The accuracy is 2^(-k)

Read more about it here
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solovay-Strassen_primality_test
Inputs : n : a value to test for primality; k : a parameter that determines the accuracy of the test
Output : composite if n is composite, otherwise probably prime
repeat k times:
x ‹— ( a / n )
if x = 0 or a ( n-1)/2 mod n <> x then return composite
return probably prime

Parameters:
n - The number to check for primality
w - The number of witnesses
Returns:
true if the number is most likely prime given the number of witnesses w.
